Description: The Death of St Antony of Egypt; the saint lying on a bed at centre and expressing his last wishes; a crucifix on the blanket; on right side the patriarch St Athanasius with his cross and pallium, St Antony giving him his cloak, and a disciple straightening the saint's pillow in background; on left side St Serapion receiving another cloak, and one of Antony's fellow-hermits (with the Tau sign) holding a candle in background; in foreground two other disciples kneeling by the bed, holding the saints's camel-hair robe; under the bed the head of a pig (St Antony's attribute); in lower left corner a holy water stoup with an aspergillium; lower left corner made up; after Peter Paul Rubens. 1649 Engraving
Curator's comments: After the painting by Rubens formerly in Castle Weissenstein, Pommersfelden (Rooses 391) but sold in 1867.
Bibliographic references: Schneevoogt 1873 / Catalogue des estampes gravées d'après P.P.Rubens (95.9)
Hollstein / Dutch and Flemish etchings, engravings and woodcuts c.1450-1700 (1.I) (under Clouet)
Associated names: Representation of: St Antony of Egypt
Representation of: St Athanasius the Great
Representation of: St Serapion of Alexandria
Acquisition name: Bequeathed by: William Fawkener (with Philipe's oval stamp and the initials WF)
